title: China Is About to Switch On 5G. It's Behind the U.S., but Not for Long.
summary: Three state-owned wireless carriers are set to open China's 5G network for public use on Friday in about 50 cities. BEIJING-China plans to turn on its first 5G networks on Friday, setting up the country to leapfrog other nations in deploying the superfast cellular technology at the center of a technological arms race between China and the U.S.

title: State Department's No. 2 Was Aware of Giuliani 'Campaign' in Ukraine
summary: John Sullivan testified at his confirmation hearing to be new U.S. ambassador to Russia. WASHINGTON-Deputy Secretary of State John Sullivan told senators that he was aware of a "campaign" by Rudy Giuliani, President Trump's personal lawyer, to oust the U.S. ambassador to Ukraine.

title: Samsung's Earnings Fall Sharply
summary: World's largest producer of memory chips reports 52% drop in third-quarter profit. SEOUL- Samsung Electronics Co. 's third-quarter net profit fell sharply, pressured by a downturn in the memory-chip market, despite growth at its mobile and display businesses.

title: United Auto Workers Strikes Tentative Labor Deal With Ford
summary: Deal must still be approved by workers. The United Auto Workers said Wednesday it has struck a new tentative labor deal with Ford Motor Co., as union bargainers look to move quickly to wrap up contract talks following a 40-day strike at General Motors Co.

title: U.S. Destroyed Baghdadi Compound to Prevent Shrine to Terror Leader
summary: Islamic State founder may have tried to shoot at U.S. forces closing in on tunnel, top military commander says. WASHINGTON-U.S. military special operations forces destroyed the compound where a raid last weekend led to the death of Islamic State founder Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi to assure that the site didn't become a shrine to the extremist leader, a top commander said Wednesday.

title: Boeing Employees Flagged Concerns About 737 MAX, Production Pressures
summary: House hearing includes company documents and further testimony by plane maker's CEO following two fatal crashes. Lawmakers looking into Boeing Co. 's grounded 737 MAX jet fleet portrayed a corporate culture in which senior managers seemingly ignored alarm bells over safety, and they pressed the company's chief executive about whether he did enough before and after two crashes that cost 346 lives.

title: GE: It Is Hard Bringing Good Things Back to Life
summary: GE shares surged on Wednesday, but only back to the level they reached three months ago. A reputation takes a long time to build and a short time to trash, or so the saying goes. How long does it take to rebuild?

title: Victim's Family Sues Accused El Paso Shooter, His Family and 8chan
summary: Lawsuit accuses message board of encouraging violence, alleged shooter's parents and grandparents of negligence. The family of a victim killed in the August mass shooting at an El Paso, Texas, Walmart Inc. store is suing the accused gunman, his parents and grandparents and the online message board 8chan.

title: Accused 1MDB Mastermind Reaches Civil Settlement With U.S.
summary: He agrees to forfeit more than $700 million in assets, but he remains a fugitive from U.S. criminal justice system. Jho Low, the businessman-turned-fugitive accused of masterminding a multibillion-dollar fraud involving Malaysia's sovereign-wealth fund, agreed to forfeit more than $700 million in assets U.S. authorities sought to seize, according to a settlement filed Wednesday.

title: Lyft Raises Guidance, Reports Increased Revenue
summary: Stock-based compensation and related taxes tied to company's IPO weigh on bottom line. Lyft Inc. raised its outlook for the year and built on recent Wall Street momentum with results that showed a 63% increase in revenue and more earnings per rider using its ride-hailing app.

title: Twitter to Ban Political Ads
summary: CEO Jack Dorsey takes the opposite position from rival Facebook on how to deal with potentially false information on their platforms. Twitter Inc. is banning political advertising, taking the opposite position of rival Facebook Inc. on an issue that is riling campaigns and prompting social-media companies to rethink how to deal with the spread of potentially false and misleading information on their platforms.

title: U.K. Finds New Reason to Talk About Weather as December Election Nears
summary: First British election in Christmas month since 1923 gives flight to heightened meteorological discourse. LONDON-The British love talking about the weather, and now they have a new way to spin the topic: How might it affect election day on Dec. 12?

title: The Man Who Built SoftBank's Tech Fund Now Has to Fix It
summary: Resume Subscription. Flying over Europe in a private jet last year, Rajeev Misra took his shoes off and propped his bare feet on the knee of a top European soccer executive. The executive froze while Mr. Misra, head of SoftBank Group Corp.'s $100 billion Vision Fund, chatted about ways to make more money off the streaming rights for FIFA tournaments.

title: New York Transit Workers Hold Massive Rally Over Contract
summary: Resume Subscription. Thousands of subway and bus workers crowded lower Manhattan on Wednesday evening to demonstrate their rising anger over stalled contract talks with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: BYO Cloud: Iron Mountain CIO Comes With G Suite
summary: Kim Anstett is rolling out Google's cloud tools at document-storage company after using them at Nielsen. When Kim Anstett left Nielsen Holdings PLC in April to become Iron Mountain Inc.'s chief information officer, she took some favorite items with her: cloud-computing, productivity and collaboration tools developed by Alphabet Inc.'s Google.

title: House Committees Seek Bolton's Testimony in Impeachment Inquiry
summary: Lawmakers want to hear from former national security adviser Nov. 7, but his attorney says he wouldn't appear voluntarily. WASHINGTON-House committees are seeking to depose John Bolton next week for their impeachment inquiry, after a series of witnesses have testified that the former national security adviser raised alarms about efforts by Rudy Giuliani and Trump administration officials to push for investigations in Ukraine.

title: Interior Department Grounds Aerial Drone Fleet, Citing Risk From Chinese Manufacturers
summary: Department has more than 800 drones, all of which are either made in China or have Chinese parts. WASHINGTON-The Interior Department is grounding its entire fleet of aerial drones, one of the largest in the federal government, citing increasing concerns about the national security risk from Chinese manufacturers.

title: Former Unaoil Chiefs Plead Guilty to U.S. Bribery Charges
summary: The plea agreements were reached three years after articles about the Monaco-based group implicated numerous energy companies. Former top executives of the Monaco-based Unaoil Group pleaded guilty to foreign bribery charges, three years after a series of articles by an Australian media company implicated the oil-services firm in a world-wide corruption scheme.

title: Fed Cuts Rate for Third Time This Year, Signals Pause
summary: Central bank statement indicates a higher bar for future rate reductions. WASHINGTON-The Federal Reserve cut interest rates for the third time this year but signaled it wouldn't reduce them further unless the economy slowed sharply.

title: Facebook Earnings Soar as Zuckerberg Warns on Politics
summary: Social-media giant's business surges as chief expresses willingness to pay price for aligning company's actions with his values. Facebook Inc.'s profit machine showed little wear and tear from the beating the social-media giant has received lately in Washington, though chief executive Mark Zuckerberg warned the political pressure could soon take a toll.

title: Mass Protests, Canceled Conferences Cloud Chilean President's Vision
summary: Sebastian Piñera has sold his country as a peaceful and prosperous place to do business, but unrest has shattered some big opportunities. SANTIAGO, Chile-President Sebastian Piñera has spent his first 20 months in office selling Chile as a prosperous and peaceful nation to foreign investors.

title: Tillerson Takes Stand in Exxon Climate Trial
summary: The oil company's former CEO says it didn't deceive investors about its accounting methods. Former Exxon Mobil Corp. Chief Executive Rex Tillerson on Wednesday testified that the company didn't mislead investors about how it accounted for climate-change regulations, taking the witness stand in a rare trial airing how businesses manage the risks of future environmental policy.

title: In California Fires, Power Outages Knock Out Modern Landline Phones
summary: State's rules don't require backup power for landline or cellphone service, leaving many customers cut off. Dayslong power outages in California are revealing an inconvenient fact about modern phones: When the electricity goes out, so do they.

title: PG&E Isn't Alone in Facing Liability Risk Over California Fires
summary: Los Angeles Department of Water and Power, Edison International are among utilities that have disclosed possible responsibility for wildfires. PG&E Corp. isn't the only California utility facing liability risks because of fires sparked by its equipment, as disclosures this week by two of the state's other top utilities show.

title: Apple Revenue Rises Even as iPhone Sales Decline
summary: Company is on track for a strong Christmas sales season, CFO says. Apple Inc. is showing it has life beyond the iPhone, reporting growth in other gadgets and services in the latest quarter that outweighed further pain in its bedrock business.

title: Popular Protests Rattle Arab Leaders
summary: Resume Subscription. BEIRUT-Waves of sustained protests have shaken entrenched Arab rulers from Algeria to Iraq, injecting a new sense of euphoria among activists across the region as more leaders succumb to demands for change.

title: Adam Smith's Revenge
summary: Trade damage takes the economy down to Obama growth levels.. The great counterfactual of the Trump Presidency is how much faster the economy would be growing without the damage of his trade protectionism. Wednesday's report of lackluster 1.9% growth in the third quarter shows again that you can't escape Adam Smith's revenge for indulging in bad economic policy for political goals.

title: Can Democrats Sell Impeachment?
summary: More than two months into their latest campaign to remove Donald Trump from office, it's hard to detect much change in public opinion.. Are Democrats making any progress in their latest attempt to remove America's duly-elected President from office? Several new polls suggest that Donald Trump remains just about as unpopular as ever. And Americans don't much care for his opponents, either.

title: America's Schools Flunk
summary: Despite more spending, test scores fall and the achievement gap grows.. The highest-achieving students are doing better and the lowest are doing worse than a decade ago. That's one depressing revelation from the latest Nation's Report Card that details how America's union-run public schools are flunking.

title: Adios, Bias Response Team
summary: Michigan concedes that its speech police are legally indefensible.. Good news is hard to find on American campuses these days, so we're even happier than usual to report a victory for free speech at the University of Michigan. The school administration has agreed under legal duress to disband its speech police and reform its student code.

title: The ABA Strikes Again
summary: The lawyers' guild tries to defeat another conservative nominee.. How can a judicial nominee who has edited the Harvard Law Review, clerked for a top circuit judge, litigated extensively at the district and appellate levels and served as Solicitor General of two states be deemed "unqualified" for the bench?

title: Facebook Earnings Overpower Critics for Now
summary: The social-media company delivered another strong quarter, but the stock's boost may not last. After defending his company at just about every venue imaginable over the past few months, it is a wonder that Facebook Chief Executive Mark Zuckerberg still has a voice. But while his platforms continue to command a growing audience, it remains to be seen whether investors will remain enraptured.

title: Au Revoir, Foie Gras: New York City Bans Sale of Delicacy
summary: A spokeswoman for Mayor Bill de Blasio says he supports the bill. The New York City Council dealt a blow to fine dining and duck farmers on Wednesday, approving a bill that bans the sale of foie gras.

title: After Baghdadi, Terrorism Without Ideology
summary: ISIS provided a template for attacks. Now isolated people reproduce them as meaningless spectacle.. Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi is dead, a few weeks after Europe was racked by four separate incidents classified as terrorism: a truck-ramming in Limburg, Germany; a series of stabbings at a police station in Paris; a shooting at a synagogue in Halle, Germany; and another set of stabbings at a shopping mall in Manchester, England. While the investigations are still under way, at this stage it doesn't appear that any of these attacks had any structured link to a terrorist group like Baghdadi's Islamic State. Most of the perpetrators displayed some awareness of an extremist ideology, but we don't know that any of them were directed to do what they did.

title: Another Smear Campaign From the American Bar Association
summary: The lawyers group declares Lawrence VanDyke 'not qualified' based on claims from anonymous critics.. If Benjamin Franklin ever had a bad idea, it was to trust lawyers to pick federal judges. According to James Madison's notes from the 1787 Constitutional Convention, Franklin suggested that an issue of such "great moment" as judicial appointments deserved a little creative thinking. And so he described-"in a brief and entertaining manner"-the Scottish tradition, "in which the nomination proceeded from the lawyers."

title: Regulators Wonder if Cancer Patients 'Need' New Treatments
summary: Michigan hospitals may spend years seeking approval for a therapy already endorsed by the FDA.. Breakthroughs against cancer are devilishly hard to come by, as millions of Americans learn firsthand each year. Yet regulators in one state want to use an outdated law to bar desperate cancer patients from the latest hard-won treatment.

title: Starbucks Gets a Lift From Iced Coffee
summary: Cold drinks now account for about half of the chain's beverage sales; shares climb in after-hours trading. Cold coffee is warming up Starbucks Corp.'s U.S. sales.

title: 'The In-Betweens' Review: They See Dead People
summary: A visit to Camp Etna, a 143-year-old retreat in the Maine woods where Spiritualists and mediums gather to commune with the dead.. Who doesn't like a good ghost story? And in Camp Etna, the 143-year-old Spiritualist summer retreat located in the Maine hinterland just west of Bangor, author Mira Ptacin has found a whopping good one. To be clear, the Spiritualism involved is not the New Age "I'm-not-religious-I'm-spiritual" variety. It is a legally recognized, federally tax-exempt religion, with ministers, weekly services and a standard creed. Basically, Spiritualists believe in two things: the Golden Rule and the ability of the living to communicate with the dead.

title: Casino Giant MGM Looking to Sell More Las Vegas Strip Real Estate
summary: The company reported a quarterly loss due in part to an impairment charge related to its sale of Circus Circus. MGM Resorts International is working toward a deal to sell another Las Vegas Strip casino, the MGM Grand, before the end of the year, part of a continuing strategy to pull cash out of its real estate, company officials said Wednesday.

title: The Democrats' Spooky Politics
summary: Their party's presidential candidates have created a bogeyman even scarier than Donald Trump. It's 'corporations!'. It was this weekend in 2012 that I went to a Halloween party wearing a quite realistic-looking Joe Biden mask. After about an hour, people said it was too spooky and asked me to take it off. When the Obama presidency ended, I threw the Biden mask away, assuming I'd never need it again. Wishful thinking is always a mistake.

title: Hunter Will Dog Joe Biden
summary: The Ukraine debacle eats away at the candidate's biggest strength: electability.. Joe Biden has a Hunter problem, and it's not going away. We saw that during the former Vice President's tone-deaf appearance Sunday on "60 Minutes."

title: Halloween Has Taken a Sadistic Turn
summary: We decry violence but 'decorate' our front yards with body parts.. Once upon a time, a medieval pope declared Nov. 1 a holiday to remember and honor the saints. The day was known as "All Saints Day" or "All Hallows Day." The evening before this saintly holiday was known as "All Hallows Eve," which became corrupted over time into "Halloween."

title: Notable & Quotable: Implicit Bias and Harvard
summary: 'In every other context, Harvard embraces the idea. . . . Faced on the stand with such an accusation itself, however, the college declares the concept ludicrous.'. From "Harvard Admits Its Preferences" by Heather Mac Donald in the New Criterion's November issue:

title: New California Fire Threatens Reagan Library
summary: Easy Fire in Simi Valley quickly grows to 1,300 acres, as firefighters gain ground on Sonoma's large Kincade Fire. SIMI VALLEY, Calif.-Californians faced another day of evacuations and blackouts Wednesday as some of the strongest winds of the year fueled a new blaze north of Los Angeles that threatened the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library.

title: Apple Dials Up Relief
summary: The company's forecast confirms a decent iPhone cycle lies ahead, but the stock's valuation remains rich. Even for a company the size of Apple Inc., the little things can count for a lot.

title: Bipartisan House Deal Opens Path to Citizenship for Illegal Immigrant Farmworkers
summary: Proposal eases some restrictions on agriculture industry, while requiring farmers to verify workers' status. WASHINGTON-A bipartisan group of lawmakers agreed on a deal easing restrictions on foreign agricultural workers, including a path to citizenship for the more than one million farmworkers estimated to be in the U.S. illegally.

title: Brazil Central Bank Cuts Benchmark Rate to 5%
summary: Bank indicates at least one more cut is in store. Brazil's central bank cut rates for the third time in as many months, extending a period of historically low borrowing costs that is changing consumers' and investors' behavior in a country long accustomed to high inflation and expensive credit.

title: Los Angeles Suspends Uber's Scooters Over Data Fight
summary: Uber has 10 days to appeal ruling after it failed to comply with a deadline to report usage data to the city. Los Angeles has temporarily suspended Uber Technologies Inc.'s permit to offer dockless scooters for rent, amid a deepening disagreement over the city's data-collection efforts.

title: Good Strategic Planning Can Be Productive
summary: The antidote to Mr. Wells's anecdotes is exactly the kind of deeper, more genuine thought and engagement that great strategic planning entails.. Wyatt Wells throws the baby out with the bath water in "Why 'Strategic Plans' Are Rarely Strategic-or Effective" (op-ed, Oct. 26). While he cites anecdotes to support his thesis, he neglects to mention that strategic planning, when done well, involves establishing a robust fact base, conducting rigorous analysis, surfacing the most intellectually and emotionally challenging questions for the organization, addressing those questions with genuine thought, integrity and collaboration, and communicating effectively across the organization throughout the process of developing and implementing the plan.

title: Charters: A Drain on Classic Public Schools
summary: A more apt choice of words for what is happening in Michigan, as well as Florida, would be a wasteful cash give-away of tax dollars to unaccountable privately run schools.. Your Oct. 19 editorial "Florida's Reform Momentum" was accompanied by Megan Keller's same-day "Detroit Is Making a Comeback. Can Its Schools?" (Cross Country), recounting how Detroit's public schools are moving in the "right direction" . . . even as "the rest of Michigan slides." One of the main reasons for Michigan's slippage is the state's embrace of dumb ideas cleverly labeled as "school choice." A more apt choice of words for what is happening in Michigan, as well as Florida, would be a wasteful cash give-away of tax dollars to unaccountable privately run schools.

title: Chicago Fed Board Chairwoman Pramaggiore Steps Down Amid Probe of Former Employer
summary: She resigned soon after she abruptly retired from her job as chief executive of the utilities unit of Exelon. Anne Pramaggiore has resigned from her position as chairwoman of the board of directors overseeing the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago, the bank confirmed Wednesday.

title: Don't Pack the High Court, But Have a Retirement Age
summary: Politicians should, as Chief Justice John Roberts has wisely admonished, eschew interjecting politics into our highest court.. Your editorial "Mayor Pete's Supreme Pivot" (Oct. 25) reminds voters of South Bend, Ind., Mayor Pete Buttigieg's radical approach to our third branch of government. President Franklin D. Roosevelt's failed court-packing attempt, and the political mischief which it was symptomatic of, has apparently now been forgotten and recycled, as fear among progressive voters increases as Associate Justice Ruth Bader Ginsberg battles health-related issues during the Court's new term.

title: Quids, Pros and Quos and The Trump Impeachment
summary: The etymology of "cherry picking" refers to a crane with a bucket to select the very best in a selfish manner.. Regarding Barton Swaim's "Blowing the Whistle About a Quid and a Quo" (op-ed, Oct. 25): The etymology of "cherry picking" refers to a crane with a bucket to select the very best in a selfish manner. The George W. Bush administration was accused of picking only information that supported the invasion of Iraq while ignoring (and hiding) evidence to the contrary.

title: The NCAA Enters the 21st Century. And the 20th.
summary: The governing body opens up to name/image/likeness rule changes. Also: What's up at Deadspin?. This week, the NCAA expressed its willingness to loosen restrictions on college athletes monetizing their name, image and likeness-an overdue move that signals, once more, that when the NCAA shrieks that a reasonable idea is bad for college sports, someone should immediately, loudly, play "Yakety Sax" on a 10-cent kazoo.

title: To Fight California Fires, Firefighters Seek to Hold the Line in Sonoma
summary: Resume Subscription. SONOMA COUNTY, Calif.-For Theodore Hiner Jr. and his crew of Grizzly Firefighters, the mission of the day was to fight any re-ignitions of the Kincade Fire literally by hand, chain-sawing brush, digging out underground flames and hand-pumping water into fresh ditches.

title: PG&E Trade Punishes Hedge Funds as California Burns
summary: Investors in utility's stocks and bonds lose $4.1 billion in four trading days. The Kincade Fire blazing north of San Francisco is wreaking havoc thousands of miles away: on Wall Street.

title: New York City Approves Major Revamp of Streets
summary: Legislation mandates a master plan to improve pedestrian and cyclist safety. New York City is about to embark upon a large-scale overhaul of its streets, taking space from cars and trucks in favor of pedestrians, cyclists and bus riders.

title: CEO of Car-Leasing Startup Fair Resigns
summary: SoftBank-backed company fired 40% of its staff last week. The founder and chief executive of troubled car-leasing startup Fair resigned Wednesday, following widespread layoffs as the company seeks a path to profitability and considers changes to its business model.

title: Ebbing Volatility Fuels Rush for Bullish Options
summary: The dwindling market volatility and rising share prices have stoked demand for options that would pay out if the S&P 500 continued to rise. The recent lurch higher in the stock market has pushed volatility lower and spurred a chase for bullish options bets on the S&P 500.

title: Tupperware Plunges as Consumer Challenges Linger
summary: Company lowers financial expectations for the year. Shares of Tupperware Brands Corp. lost more than a third of their value after the company lowered its financial expectations for the year as it continues to struggle with a consumer pullback in its key markets.

title: S&P 500 Closes at Fresh High After Rate Cut
summary: Stock benchmarks rise after Federal Reserve's latest interest-rate move. The S&P 500 notched its second record close of the week after the Federal Reserve cut interest rates again and signaled its intention to keep rates low.

title: Trump's Disfavor Hangs Over Possible Sessions Senate Bid
summary: Former attorney general is weighing a run in Alabama, but his poor relationship with the president could hurt his GOP primary chances.. As former Attorney General Jeff Sessions weighs a run for his old Senate seat in Alabama, Republicans say one person can all but doom his chances: President Trump.

title: Malware Detected at India's Largest Nuclear Power Plant
summary: State-run power producer says infected computer wasn't connected to facility's control system. NEW DELHI-India's state-run nuclear power producer said malware was discovered on a computer at its largest facility earlier this year but the computer wasn't connected to the plant's operations, which it said were unaffected.

title: GE Posts Loss on Restructuring, Lifts Cash-Flow Goals
summary: Conglomerate now expects up to $2 billion in 2019 cash flow from industrial operations. General Electric Co. reported a $9.5 billion third-quarter loss weighed down by accounting charges, but the industrial conglomerate showed signs of progress and again raised its cash-flow outlook for the year.

title: Philip Roth Left More Than $2 Million to His Hometown Library in Newark, N.J.
summary: The writer, who grew up in Newark, quietly arranged to bequeath a large portion of his estate to the Newark Public Library before he died last year. Philip Roth, the Pulitzer Prize-winning novelist, quietly arranged to give at least $2 million of his estimated $10 million estate to the Newark, N.J., public library before his death last year.

title: Cash-Market Volatility Adds to Worries Facing Libor Replacement
summary: Issuance of floating-rate debt linked to the secured overnight financing rate falls sharply in October. Turmoil in short-term money markets has rattled a protracted effort to phase in a new borrowing benchmark meant to eventually underpin trillions of dollars in lending contracts.

title: Credit Suisse Posts Strong Profit, Boosted by Fund Platform Sale
summary: Swiss banking giant warns that Brexit and U.S.-China trade tensions may make investors more cautious. Credit Suisse Group AG's third-quarter net profit more than doubled on the back of strong results in global markets and the sale of a fund platform, though results in its core wealth management units were weaker.

title: Kamala Harris Laying Off Staff, Moving Others to Iowa in Shake-Up
summary: California senator's campaign spent more than it raised in the last quarter. California Sen. Kamala Harris is restructuring her presidential campaign to cut costs, including laying off some staffers in her headquarters in Baltimore and deploying others to Iowa from offices in New Hampshire, Nevada and California.

title: The Fed Gives Investors an Appropriate Gift
summary: The Federal Reserve's subtle change in language sent markets the vague message it sought. Sometimes the most appropriate thing to do is to say you aren't going to act appropriately anymore.

title: Treasury Yields Fall After Fed Cuts Interest Rates
summary: Recent data shows economy continues to expand, though pace has decelerated. U.S. government bond yields fell Wednesday after the Federal Reserve cut interest rates and hinted at a pause to future cuts.

title: Tower Penthouse in a Legendary Manhattan Building
summary: In the San Remo, this triplex penthouse once owned by Demi Moore neighbors the one owned by U2 frontman Bono.. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: A Fashionable Room Designed Around Hermès Wallpaper
summary: Designer Anne Hepfer saw a reflection of the cityscape in a plaid wallcovering, against which she mapped out an urbane dining room. Here's how to get the look. BIG CITIES have a particular layout-gridded and vertical and streamlined-that accommodates lots of people but leaves them living in cramped-feeling rooms. Desks are tucked into hallway closets that get passed off as home offices; treadmills sidle up to sofas. But while many urbanites resign themselves to the limitations of high-rise-life, Toronto interior designer Anne Hepfer borrowed, and beautified, its aesthetic framework for a local client's penthouse apartment.

title: Chile Cancels APEC Summit, Where U.S. Hoped to Sign Deal With China
summary: White House had been aiming to have a phase-one trade agreement signed by Trump and Xi Jinping on meeting's sidelines. The cancellation of an Asia-Pacific summit is complicating efforts by the U.S. and China to complete and sign a limited trade agreement designed to keep new tariffs at bay.

title: Season of the Witch
summary: A restored version of Benjamin Christensen's witchy 'Häxan' allows for distraction-free viewing, letting audiences bask in and shudder at all the spooky details..

title: Bank of Canada Stands Pat on Rate
summary: Central bank keeps key interest rate unchanged at 1.75%, cites signs of resilience in Canadian economy. OTTAWA-Bank of Canada officials considered what is known as an insurance cut to shelter the economy from rising global headwinds before deciding to leave the key rate on hold this week, Governor Stephen Poloz said.

title: U.S. Growth Settles in at Low Gear in Third Quarter
summary: Consumer spending growth offsets business investment decline in 1.9% GDP increase. WASHINGTON-U.S. economic growth settled in at a lower gear in the third quarter, with consumer spending and housing investment increases offsetting a business investment drop.

title: 'The Turn of the Screw,' 'Zauberland' and 'En Masse' Reviews
summary: Benjamin Britten's opera gets a staging in an appropriately creepy setting; a contorted take on traditional lieder concerts; and the end of one world meets the beginning of a new one..

title: Arnold Schwarzenegger on Why Jealousy Is a Good Thing
summary: The former governor and perennial Terminator on keeping up with Sylvester Stallone, playing a cyborg at age 72 and his electric Hummer. WHILE FACETIMING us from London's Heathrow airport, Arnold Schwarzenegger sipped from a pink tea set he called "cutsey wootsy." But even when he's equipped with delicate accessories, there's nothing dainty about the imposing bodybuilder turned film star turned governor.

title: Fed Rate Cut Generates Dissents From Two Fed Officials
summary: Eric Rosengren of Boston and Esther George of Kansas City continue to dissent on reductions. WASHINGTON-The Federal Reserve's decision Wednesday to lower interest rates generated less internal opposition than its similar reduction last month.

title: Russia's Gas Pipeline to Germany Clears Major Hurdle
summary: Denmark allows construction of Trump-opposed project that has also divided the European Union. BRUSSELS-Russia cleared a major hurdle in building a gas pipeline to Germany that President Trump has fiercely opposed after Denmark on Wednesday granted the final construction permits.

title: Japan, Russia Take Steps Toward Resolving Territorial Dispute
summary: Japanese tourists to visit contested islands that have long been a source of conflict between the two countries. Russia and Japan launched a new program aimed at resolving a territorial dispute that has festered between the neighbors for decades, as a group of Japanese tourists departed for a visit to a group of contested islands.

title: Facebook Takes Down Inauthentic Accounts It Links to Russian
summary: Yevgeny Prigozhin has previously been indicted by the Justice Department for allegedly orchestrating a campaign on Moscow's behalf to influence the 2016 U.S. presidential election. Facebook Inc. said it dismantled a coordinated effort to mislead users led by a Russian businessman whom law-enforcement officials have previously accused of interfering in U.S. elections.

title: Deutsche Bank Must Show It Can Do More Than Just Shrink
summary: The German banking giant says it is hitting restructuring goals, but investors are far from convinced. Deutsche Bank says its restructuring is on track, but investors are clearly impatient with the bank to start showing signs of life.

title: Bayer Reports Surge in Roundup Plaintiffs
summary: Number of people claiming herbicide caused cancer has more than doubled in past three months. BERLIN- Bayer AG said the number of plaintiffs claiming its Roundup herbicides caused cancer more than doubled to 42,700 in the past three months, adding pressure on the company to resolve the legal battle that has raised questions about its future.

title: HBO Max: What We Know and Don't Know
summary: Tuesday's unveiling left open several questions about access to the service for existing HBO customers. AT&T Inc. has revealed key details about its new HBO Max streaming-video service ahead of the app's launch next year, though some questions remain unanswered.

title: Deutsche Bank Suffers Another Loss as Restructuring Bites
summary: Shares in German lender fall sharply after loss exceeded expectations. Deutsche Bank AG posted its second straight quarterly loss, as the troubled lender absorbed costs from its sweeping restructuring and its key fixed-income business performed poorly.

title: What the Interest Rate Cut Means for You
summary: How the Fed's move can affect your day-to-day finances. The Federal Reserve cut its short-term benchmark rate by a quarter-percentage point for the third time this year on Wednesday, lowering the federal-funds rate to a range between 1.5% and 1.75%.

title: Students Show Declines in Nation's Report Card
summary: Fourth-grade math is only bright spot in test given nationally every two years. American students continued a pattern of failing to make notable gains in a national exam, with result scores dropping in nearly all categories and on par with those from a decade ago.

title: Are Jumpsuits the New Chef Whites?
summary: Forget the Frenchie toque and starched apron. One chef is making chef jumpsuits-part of a suite of new collaborations in the fashion-meets-culinary space. Chef Missy Robbins, 48, is probably the last person who thought her signature look would be a jumpsuit.

title: U.K. Regulator Pushes for Improved Financial Reports
summary: Companies continue to make mistakes calculating cash flows and provide too little information about alternative performance measures, the Financial Reporting Council says. The U.K. Financial Reporting Council is calling upon audit committee chairs and finance directors to boost the quality of their companies' financial reports, a move that comes on the heels of a review in which the accounting regulator found room for substantial improvement.

title: Brazil Should Say NOPEC to OPEC
summary: Jair Bolsonaro shouldn't push to be a member of the oil exporters' club even though they would love to have him. Someone explain the concept of being an economic free rider to this man.

title: Options Project Calm for Online Travel Stocks
summary: Swings for Expedia, TripAdvisor and Booking are expected to hover below average moves recorded in previous eight earnings releases. Options traders are bracing for a relatively calm earnings season for online travel stocks, despite big swings in shares of individual companies this reporting season.

title: For a Luxe Fly Fishing Trip, Try Bermuda
summary: On this island of rum swizzles and posh golf resorts, an angler goes in search of the elusive bonefish. I HAD NEVER considered fly fishing for bonefish in Bermuda. Chasing the elusive, silver-green creatures, prized for their fight, was something you did at remote outposts and rustic camps, where showering was optional and accommodations primitive. Such a trip could be fun for a few days, but you'd never dare drag your wife or kids along. And fly fishing is hardly the first thing to come to mind on an island of genteel sports like cricket, golf, tennis, sailing and snorkeling. In Bermuda, even cocktailing is arguably a sport. Most visitors completely fail to explore the possibilities for inshore fishing, specifically with a fly rod.

title: Mexican Economy Barely Grew in Third Quarter
summary: GDP rose 0.1% from second quarter, with industrial output shrinking 0.1% and services unchanged. MEXICO CITY-Mexico's economy barely grew in the third quarter amid weakness in industrial production and a slowdown in services, keeping the economy on track this year for its weakest performance in a decade.

title: Pittsburgh Plans to Appeal Ruling Against New Gun Laws
summary: Trio of gun laws were passed by city in wake of Tree of Life shooting that killed 11. Pittsburgh officials vowed to appeal a judge's ruling Tuesday that struck down gun restrictions imposed by the city council after last year's synagogue massacre.

summary: New HBO service is priced above most rivals, but telecom giant had little choice. AT&T was between a rock and a hard place with its much-awaited entry into the TV streaming wars. It chose the hard place.

title: Trump's Tax Cut Underdelivers, Which Could Embolden Democrats
summary: Democrats hope to make the economy, inequality and the middle class central to the 2020 election. The cornerstone of President Trump's domestic economic agenda is the tax cut he signed into law in late 2017. It would, he said, lift U.S. sustained annual economic growth to 3%, or even as high as 6%. His advisers said it would boost average household incomes by at least $4,000 a year. His Treasury secretary said it would pay for itself.

summary: Social-media company refuses to admit liability over political firm's improper access to users' data. summary: Parents hone strategies that let children trick-or-treat without triggering a bender on fun-size sweets. Just 20% of moms and dads said they don't set limits on their children's Halloween candy, according to a survey of more than 2,000 parents conducted last week by Pittsburgh consumer-research firm CivicScience.

title: China Seeks to Reassure Over Small Rural Bank's Health
summary: Henan Yichuan Rural Commercial Bank has seen a flurry of withdrawals, and its former chairman is under investigation. BEIJING-A small Chinese rural bank became the latest lender to spark concern as authorities were forced Wednesday to assure the safety of its deposits following a flurry of withdrawals, and as China's anticorruption watchdog unveiled an investigation of the bank's former chairman.

title: For Shia LaBeouf and Alma Har'el, 'Honey Boy' Was an Act of Therapy
summary: In her debut scripted film, 'Honey Boy,' director Alma Har'el worked with actor and screenwriter Shia LaBeouf to tap into his childhood. The pair "come from a similar pain index," LaBeouf says. Director Alma Har'el didn't go to a traditional film school. "My filmmaking has been kind of pulling from everywhere," says the 41-year-old, whose latest project, Honey Boy, comes out November 8. Her cinematic education started during her childhood in Rehovot, Israel, where Har'el and her two siblings lived with their mother and grandmother, while her parents "tried to make it work over the years." When the couple was on shaky ground, her father, who, she says, has struggled with alcoholism, wouldn't be allowed in the house. "But once a week we'd go see a movie together," says Har'el. "It was the best thing ever. He was a tough critic, but his taste was pretty broad."

title: Novartis Trial of World's Most Expensive Drug Halted Over Safety Concerns
summary: Drug maker hoped to broaden its market for gene therapy drug Zolgensma. Novartis AG has paused a clinical trial of its Zolgensma gene therapy after a separate study on animals raised concerns about side effects, dealing a setback to the company's efforts to broaden the market for the world's most expensive drug.

title: Melina Matsoukas's Fearless Vision
summary: As an award-winning director with standout collaborators (Beyoncé, Rihanna, Issa Rae), Melina Matsoukas has created some of music and television's more memorable moments. Now, with 'Queen & Slim,' she makes her feature film debut. How does a contemporary filmmaker make entertaining black art that also responds to the world we live in? I am preoccupied with this question as I sit down with director Melina Matsoukas. Just before our conversation, I'd watched an early screening of her first feature film. I was transfixed. As the final credits rolled, I sobbed-I was utterly wrecked. Queen & Slim, a romantic thriller starring Jodie Turner-Smith and Daniel Kaluuya in the title roles, is by far the blackest movie I've ever seen. As engrossing as it is political, the movie is an unequivocal rejoinder to the world we live in, where police brutality is a pervasive and omnipresent reality, and where a great many people still need to be reminded that black lives matter.
